Caption: Fig. 1: Our proposed framework helps domain experts evaluate and develop order selection criteria for autoregressive processes. (1) A customizable evaluation thread is constantly running in the background, creating synthetic autoregressive processes to test user-defined selection criteria in real-time. (2) A scripting interface enables users to input existing, or to define new, order selection criteria to be evaluated. (3) Interactive visualizations give responsive feedback of the current evaluation status and allow insight into the quality of the selection criteria.

Fig. 2: Overview of our visual analytics framework. Using the vi- sual interface, the user provides (1) settings for the synthetic process generator as well as (2) order selection criteria to be evaluated. (3) Realizations of the processes are generated and used to test the given selection criteria. The visual interface receives live feedback from the evaluation and constantly updates the visualization. Based on this re- sponsive visual feedback, experts can quickly perform fine-tuning of selection criteria or alter generator settings.

Fig. 3: Conceptual illustration of an order selection criterion. For each order, the selection criterion returns the fitting error with an additional penalty for model size. The order for which the selection criterion returns the minimum value is considered the best fit.

Fig. 4: Distribution of the complex roots of 10000 random stationary AR(4) processes shown in the unit circle. (a) The sufficient condition samples only from a limited set of possible AR processes. (b) The Beadle and Djurić algorithm non-uniformly samples from all possible AR processes. (c) Our method uniformly samples from all possible AR processes, but also allows customizing the distribution function.

Fig. 5: (1) Our root distribution widget. (2) Additional evaluation settings. (3) Selection criteria are shown in a list with their corresponding colors. New selection criteria may be added and existing ones may be edited using a scripting interface. If an order selection criterion is clicked by the user, three specialized views (6,7,8) become available. (4) A line graph compares the success percentage for all selection criteria. (5) An interactive line graph shows the distribution of guesses for a user-selected order (here order 4). (6) A deviation plot compares the average guess for the active selection criterion with the perfect fit (gray line). (7) A bar graph shows the average value of the active criterion for the user-selected order (here order 4), contrasted with the residual variance (gray). The minimum (best fit) is additionally highlighted. (8) Another deviation plot shows the minimum average value of the active selection criterion for each order. This visualization works as an overview for (7).

New selection criteria may be added and existing ones may be edited using a scripting interface. Fig. 8: Comparison of the output of (a) the FBIC (purple) and (b) the AIC (red). The gray bars in each plot are the logarithm of the residual variance, while the colored bars represent the remaining penalty term introduced by the respective selection criterion. The highlighted bar in each plot shows the minimum, i.e., the selected order.

Fig. 7: Example for the interactive Guess Distribution plot, showing the AIC (red), BIC (green), FAIC (blue), FBIC (purple) order selection criteria. All criteria have a low success rate for the observed (correct) order 9. Additionally, the non-finite sample criteria AIC and BIC both show significant overfit at orders 11 and 12.

Fig. 9: Average running times for one trial with a given maximum order and a sample size of 100 and the AIC for order selection. Each plot uses a different parameter estimation method. From left to right: Yule-Walker, Burg, and Least Squares. The timings of each individual step—i.e. process generation (orange), parameter estimation (green), and order selection (blue)—are additionally highlighted. We observe that the less frequently used Least Squares estimation method performs approximately ten times slower than the other two methods.

Fig. 9: Average running times for one trial with a given maximum order and a sample size of 100 and the AIC for order selection. Each plot uses a different parameter estimation method. From left to right: Yule-Walker, Burg, and Least Squares. The timings of each individual step—i.e. process generation (orange), parameter estimation (green), and order selection (blue)—are additionally highlighted. We observe that the less frequently used Least Squares estimation method performs approximately ten times slower than the other two methods.

Fig. 13: Selection offset of the AIC for the nuclear reactor example. Each plot shows the selection offset for the corresponding root distri- bution in Figure 12. We observe that the AIC tends to overfit for root distributions closer to boundary of the unit circle.

Fig. 12: Evaluation of order selection criteria for detecting anomalies in reactor operations using the properties of the 1994 IAEA bench- mark. Each row shows the success rates for the AIC (red), BIC (green), and HQC (blue) and the corresponding root distribution: (a) Gaussian distribution, (b) Gaussian with lower bound, (c) near-unit distribution. We observe that the relative accuracy of the selection criteria remains the same for all root distributions near the unit circle.

Fig. 11: Guess Distributions of the AIC (red), AICF (green), AICc (blue), and FAIC (purple) for the near-unit root distribution, Fig. 10. (a) For the Yule-Walker parameter estimation method, we observe that all criteria have a tendency to underfit, especially to pick order 1. (b) For the Burg method, this tendency disappears and the overall success rate increases. However, a tendency to overfit is apparent.

Fig. 14: Average guess for the HQC (left) and the BIC (right). We observe that for order 1 the HQC shows little error, as opposed to the BIC. The BIC, on the other hand, shows less underfitting overall.

Fig. 14: Average guess for the HQC (left) and the BIC (right). We observe that for order 1 the HQC shows little error, as opposed to the BIC. The BIC, on the other hand, shows less underfitting overall.
